docs.text: Letter #8 - May 7, 2020 Psalm 56:8-13 "You have kept count of my tossings; put my tears in your bottle. Are they not in your book? Then my enemies will turn back in the day when I call. This I know, that God is for me. In God, whose word I praise, in the Lord, whose word I praise, in God I trust; I shall not be afraid. What can man do to me? I must perform my vows to you, O God; I will render thank offerings to you. For you have delivered my soul from death, yes, my feet from falling, that I may walk before God in the light of life." Dear Church Family, This is a devotional shared yesterday by our friends at FBC South New Berlin. I think it is right on the mark for insight and encouragement for this week. I hope you enjoy it as much as I did. Blessings of God's peace and health, Pastor Kurt GOD IS FOR YOU! Sharing A Women Of Faith Devotion "Is it easiest to trust God in the midst of trials or happy times?" The question was asked to a group attending a youth group camping trip. "During the happy times" is what I expected to hear from everyone, however it wasn't so. It was probably split 50/50, actually, depending on how each person dealt with trials, what they'd been through, and so on. One of the girls spoke up and said, "When times are good, I just worry about all the bad things that could happen. When I'm going through difficult times, the only thing I am able to cling to is God's promises." Fast forward to now and we are all facing a global pandemic. It seems important now to understand the last bit of that wisdom. Time to cling to Scripture, and begin studying what God's Word says about suffering. Psalm 56 ---particularly the last half: "You have kept count of my tossings; put my tears in your bottle. Are they not in your book? Then my enemies will turn back in the day when I call. This I know, that God is for me. In God, whose word I praise, in the Lord, whose word I praise, in God I trust; I shall not be afraid. What can man do to me? I must perform my vows to you, O God; I will render thank offerings to you. For you have delivered my soul from death, yes, my feet from falling, that I may walk before God in the light of life." --- Psalm 56:8-13 Yes, the psalmist's situation was a little different---crying out to God for help in the midst of persecution. Yet his string of emotions throughout Psalm 56 rings true for many: a cry for help, an expression of his confidence in God's power to save, a request that God justify the suffering he's going through, and a promise of his vows to God. "You kept a count of my tossings . . ." uses the Hebrew word "nodiy" which appears only here in the Old Testament. It most likely comes from the word "nadad," meaning "to wander," expressing the psalmist's deep distress and lost feelings. Yet ". . . put my tears in your bottle" reminds us that God observes our afflictions with compassion and tender concern, he is afflicted by our afflictions, and he knows our souls in adversity. Lamenters often complain that God is absent or doesn't notice their trials, yet he expresses confidence that God watches over him, even in the midst of suffering. Belief mixed with frustration, tears mixed with joy, fear mixed with faith. Yet, through it all, confidence in God's faithfulness, because he knew God was for him. We may not know what tomorrow holds. We may go through periods when we think we just won't be able to make it. We might shed countless tears. Despite it all, we know that he works all things for good ( Romans 8:28 ). Despite all odds, we know that God is for us . It is for this reason we need to praise his word, or as the original translation puts it---we "shine, radiate, and are visible" in our praise. Even in the midst of suffering. We can't see the full picture, we know that God is faithful---because he has already delivered us from death, that we might walk before God in the light of life. Remember those in our Prayers Mikey and Lewis Piliaro, Jean and Tim Furner, Amanda Dunham, Betty Benson, Bryer, my two year old grandson who has been sick the last three days, Mary Grace and Conrad, and all folks who are residents in nursing homes and adult homes, all first responders and healthcare workers, all high school seniors disappointed with not being able to have a normal graduation ceremony in June, all college students with schedule interruptions and changes for next year. Many colleges will not begin regular classes until January. Prayers for the well being of our countrymen and our friends in need around the world. Praise: Positive signs that our state's regulations on stay at home and social distancing are working. The curve of the infection has begun to flatten dramatically. Praise God! To God for many gifted, hard working people developing treatments and vaccines to help against the Covid 19 virus. Announcements: Topic: Kurt Funke's Sunday Service Zoom Meeting Time: 10:30 AM Sunday Join Zoom Meeting https://us02web.zoom.us/j/5051711585?pwd=aml0YjZodmNXQUhFNlhOaGo1Mk5tUT09 Meeting ID: 505 171 1585 Password: 3156914301 One tap mobile +19292056099,,5051711585#,,1#,3156914301# US (New York) Dial by your location +1 929 205 6099 US (New York) Giving: If you would like to dedicate some funds in the U.S. to the fight against issues related to the Covid 19 virus, please send in an offering check to Jean earmarked One Great Hour of Sharing (OGHS) U.S. And Puerto Rico. Also, thank you for remembering to give your ties and offerings to the church on a regular basis. Lord, make us an instrument of Your peace. Where there is hatred, let us sow love; Where there is injury, pardon; Where there is doubt, faith; Where there is despair, hope; Where there is darkness, light; Where there is sadness, Joy... Lord, thank you for giving us the spiritual tools to get through the most challenging of times, and yet be an instrument of Your peace, a conduit of Your Love. In Jesus name...Amen
